thread.section_title: Orlando Sentinel- Orlando news, sports and more
thread.title: UCF athletics lands $5 million donation - largest in history by an alumnus
thread.title_full: UCF athletics lands $5 million donation - largest in history by an alumnus

author: Gabrielle Russon
title: UCF athletics lands $5 million donation - largest in history by an alumnus
text:
UCF athletics lands $5 million donation - largest in history by an alumnus UCF Knights An archived photo of the UCF Knights. An archived photo of the UCF Knights. (Orlando Sentinel) Gabrielle Russon athletics department received a $5 million pledge Wednesday, its largest gift ever from an alumnus.
The donation, which the university will receive over 10 years, is the main issue to be discussed Friday during a trustees meeting, according to the board agenda released Wednesday. 
For Ken Dixon, a real estate developer from Kissimmee, it’s the second time he’s donated a significant sum to the school. 
“They’re going to spend the money as they need fit. I don’t like to direct it,” said Dixon, who graduated in 1975 from UCF with an accounting degree. “This is money I’m giving to the athletic department to do the things they need to do to hopefully make it a Top 25 program one of these days.” 
Some athletic needs include walkways and building signs as well as other priorities for UCF sports set by athletic director Danny White, the school documents said. 
Dixon said he wanted to give money that would have a “lasting impact” to be something “around a long time, long after I’m gone.” 
With the donation, the school will give him naming rights to what they described as an “athletics village,” pending trustee approval. The village will consist of the 95 acres where CFE Arena, Bright House Networks Football Stadium as well as the sports facilities are located. 
Dixon’s name is already a familiar one around campus. 
The accounting school is named after Dixon after he donated $2.5 million, an amount that grew larger because it was also eligible for state matching funds. He made the donation to the academic department in 2004. 
UCF Foundation CEO Michael Morsberger could not be reached for comment late Wednesday. Morsberger is leading the foundation’s $500 million fundraising campaign that officially kicked off in September.

Mid-rise apartments have also been built next to SunRail stations in Lake Mary, Longwood and Maitland in the past two years. For businesses, these structures can bring a boon of new customers, but for some residents, they’re a threat to the quaint aesthetic that drew them to some of Orlando’s most in-demand neighborhoods.
